title.rendered: 10 games to learn programming for kids

content.rendered:
They say that learning through play is the best way. This is especially true for young children. If you’re thinking of introducing your kids to coding, you might want to try learning to code games for kids. From Scratch to Minecraft, here’s our list of the top contenders for your kid’s coding teacher spot!

Programming in a nutshell

You’ve probably heard by now that in some way coding is perfect for kids and their education from a young age. We can’t but agree – programming is the 21st century skill that creates a completely different, empowering relationship with technology and fosters diverse skills such as reasoning, communication, creativity and even math skills. We already talked about the myriad benefits of coding in a previous blog post.

So we’ve already established why programming itself is so incredibly useful for your kids. The sooner they pick up the basics of programming (like any other language), the better the chances they’ll learn quickly and absorb it naturally. If you’re still wondering how to go about it because you might not be a programming expert yourself, we have a useful suggestion for you – Games to learn programming for kids. But why programming games at all?

Learning to code games for kids – why these are good educational tools

On our blog we have already discussed why learning through play is so practical for children. You can find the article here. In summary, learning through play is very natural for children. They experiment, tinker, observe, design and build with their previous experiences without realizing it. Learning through play mimics real-world problem solving for little ones. Play makes the learning process smoother and more fun than sitting at a desk listening to a lecture.

Another reason why games for kids to learn to code are a good idea is that storytelling of games. Storytelling is another learning environment that children enjoy and are used to, as we have also discussed here. For example, at Robo prodigy all programming lessons built around creative stories, which engages children’s minds and humanizes learning. Engaging storytelling draws children into the storyline and allows them to relate to the characters. Stories can also promote understanding and create an environment in which the child feels comfortable, relaxed, and open to new information.

Top 10 Learning Coding Games for Kids to Try

So what programming games for kids meet these criteria of engaging storytelling and well-structured game-based education? We have made a list of 10 notable games. We’ve discussed benefits as well as age appropriateness so you can choose the best games for your kids or students to learn to code.

1. Minecraft

Minecraft is a well-known game that adapts to the user – from simple constructions to complex worlds, everyone can find something appropriate for their age here. Children can start building simple objects and then progress to building their own games within the game itself. Minecraft is available for all operating systems and prices start at €7.99 (depending on the operating system).

2. Tynker

Tynker is another game for learning programming that has different levels of difficulty for kids of different ages (basically suitable from 6-7 years old). It’s visually designed and compelling, and it’s subscription-based. The first 10 levels and activities are free, so you can try it and see if you like it. Finally, your child can also learn more complex programming languages ​​such as Python or JavaScript through the game.

3. CodeMonkey

Code Monkey is a coding platform that allows kids to learn several different programming languages ​​with no prior experience, so it’s perfect for getting started. There is a range of programming courses as well as full curriculum that is ideal not only for parents and students but also for educators to incorporate into the classroom. A pricing plan can be requested depending on class size and requirements, with the option of a 14 day trial offer.

4. Scratch + scratch jr

Developed in an MIT lab, this free online app features games, interactive storytelling, and even the ability to join an online community. Scratch is a programming language that is mostly visual and graphical, making it good for beginners. It can seem a bit overwhelming at the beginning, but you quickly learn how to deal with scratch. Similar to Minecraft, kids can not only play games but also create their own, which is extra motivating. In addition to Scratch, there is also Scratch Jr., a light version of the game for 5-7 year old kids. Both apps are available for iOS and Android devices.

Robo Prodigy has Scratch in our newest and most advanced programming app Robo Blockly installed for 8-16 year old children. Robo Blockly is a scratch-based app that teaches advanced programming concepts such as variables, functions, operators, and input-output mapping and offers learning to code games and challenges for kids.

5. CodeSpark Academy

This coding platform and app is for kids ages 5-9 and prides itself on an research-based curriculum and a variety of activities – from build-it-yourself games (like Minecraft and Tynker) to pre-programmed puzzles and challenges. The app is available on all devices and offers a worldwide community and support, ideal for educators and parents. You can avail a 7-day free trial offer, after that you pay $9.99 a month.

6. Lightbot

This app is similar to Minecraft with its block-based interface, but focuses more on teaching programming concepts instead of programming languages. Concepts include sequences, conditions, infinite loops, and more – perfect for those who have previous experience playing games to learn to code. Because these concepts are taught in a playful way and with a visual interface, they can be easily assimilated by younger children. The app costs 3.49 euros and is available for iOS and Android devices.

7. Codemoji

The app’s name already reveals one of its greatest appeals – a ubiquitous supply of emojis that kids love so much. The visual appeal of this app is its strongest asset, as is the natural combination of coding lessons and coding games. So kids can learn, have fun, and learn the basics of STEM at the same time. Units are self-paced so each student can take the time needed to learn the new information. The app is tailored for parents and educators who can take advantage of a 14-day trial offer with over 500 freely available lessons. The goal of the app is to teach kids the basics of computational thinking while doing the programming itself using JavaScript, CSS, HTML, and Java.

8. Blocky Games

Good news for kids (and parents or educators) who are new to coding – this site is for you. Once again, it’s more about the concepts behind programming, taught to kids through puzzle-like activities and games to learn to code. The concepts are introduced step by step and built up step by step. So don’t skip any that you don’t like! You need each unit for an accurate understanding. All levels are free.

9. Kodable

Another useful resource for parents and educators. Kodable teaches the JavaScript and Swift programming languages, while also encouraging creativity and critical thinking skills. The games are for children between the ages of 4 and 7 years and 7 and 10 years. The younger age group learns about the drag-and-drop principle of programming (pull-and-drop), while the older ones dedicate themselves to programming languages, building their own games and programming object-oriented. There is a curriculum for educators. You can start with a 7-day trial offer and then go for a monthly subscription starting at $7 or a lifetime subscription for $120. Subscribing also gives you exclusive access to the community and shared content.

10.Osmo

And one last game to learn programming for kids. Osmo is a tablet game that builds with physical objects that come with it, following the Montessori approach. Osmo can be used both at home and in the classroom. All you need is the Osmo base, the app, and the handy pieces that kids can build with while interacting with the screen. Osmo is for children aged 5 to 12 and starts at €119.95 as a basic package (you pay for the physical products, the app is free). The great thing about Osmo is that you can always build on the physical objects by buying new components. The system is simple and easy to use, with solid incremental challenges. No wonder it was developed by former Google engineers.

In addition to all the games mentioned, Robo prodigy A great introduction to learning to program at home or at school. Our modular robot kit contains color-coded building blocks that are intuitive to use and can be set up in an open-ended manner to suit even the most experienced programmer. In addition, our apps (Robo Live, Robo Code, Robo Blockly) to the cognitive needs of different age groups, so our products can be used by children between the ages of 5 and 16. We also offer themed weekly and monthly challenges for our global community, so you’ll never run out of ideas.

There is a wide range of games to learn to code – choose one and join in the fun and adventure that the world of technology has to offer!
